was impossible,
as in order to do so we would have to lose a trip
to Namyung,
which was most important.
By this time I began to real-
ize that it would be perfectly useless for me
to stay in Hongkong
any longer, and I would have to go somewhere where I could get some
rest.
my cough was getting worse, so was my leg.
Mr. Schafer volun-
teored to remain in Hongkong the next day to handle the traffic.
gave hin a list of about 10 people that
I had seen and whom I par-
ticularly wanted to get out, and Mr. P. Y. Wong also had a list of
about 15.
At that time, as far as anyone could tell, the conditions
were unchanged,
and I
saw no reason to believe that we could not
operate the
following night.
I therefore returned to
Chungking that
We continued to get
word from Namyung
that Sweet's
plane was still having mechanical
trouble; in fact,
we were informed that one of his engines had burn-
ed out a piston.
Pilot Hugh Chen, about 4 o'clock in the morning,
took the
Vultee off
and flew it to Namyung,
although it had no radio.
Also
his compass got out of order about halfway to Namyung and he cou-
pleted the trip with a pocket compass.
Namyung was overcast and
since he had no radio he could not let down.
He went on beyond, and
after daylight he found an opening and came down on a small emergency
field. He located himsolf
and
then flew back to Namyung by contact.
There he refuelled and continued his flight to Chungking where he
landed safely.
Pilot Scott started out about the same time with the remain-
toots cotta pit
containing two new G103 engines, one of which we intended
The Condor also had no radio.
However,
Scott developed ignition trouble shortly after his take off and re-
turned to Kaltak.
This Condor was
of those given to Eurasia and
which they had never flown. He got back to Hongkong in time to come
cut on the last DC-3.
When I arrived in Chungking,
Sharp and Woods and myself bo-
gan to make plans to send the two DC-3's and one DC-2 that night
(Wednesday) to Hongkong.
Sharp planned to go back as passenger and
attempt to take the Concor out with the two
engines.
However, just
as we
had perfected our arrangements, we received a message from
Moss instructing us not to return that night, giving no reasons.
As there were three people sleeping in every
room in the
place where I llve and I was by then really
in need of rest,
I de-
cided to go over to the South Bank and spend the night with chugh,
who was very cordial and offered me a bed and room to myself. As
there was nothing more I could do that day, I went over to the South
Bank and went to bed about 1:30.
I had been awake for over 53 hours
and on duty practically the whole time. When I undressed to go to
bed over
there,
I discovered that I had broken several blood vessels
in my left leg,
walch was badly swollen.
ly foot and ankle were as
black as
your
hat and my leg was yellow. I stayed In bed until 8
the next morning,
and felt much better.
resume service to Hongkong; also considerable criticisms against
